sections.title: 1. Liar Paradox

sections.title: 2. Russell's Paradox
sections.txt_claim: Statement: Let R = {x | x âˆ‰ x}. Does R âˆˆ R? Formal Dissolution (PXL): Let R = proposed set of all sets not containing themselves. Traditional: R âˆˆ R â†” R âˆ‰ R (contradiction). PXL Analysis: Set formation requires: â–¡(âˆƒS)(ğ•€â‚(S) âˆ§ âˆ€x âˆˆ S: ğ•€â‚(x)). R attempts definition: R = {x | Â¬(x âˆˆ x)}. Identity check: ğ•€â‚(R) requires R to be well-defined before membership test. But R's definition is: R âˆˆ R âŸº Â¬(R âˆˆ R). This creates: ğ•€â‚(R) âŠ— ğ•€â‚‚(Â¬(R âˆˆ R)) = âŠ¥. Resolution: R âˆ‰ Dom(ğ•€â‚) âˆ´ R is not a set in ğ•†.

sections.title: 3. Curry's Paradox
sections.txt_claim: Statement: Let C = 'If this sentence is true, then P' for arbitrary P. Formal Dissolution (PXL): Let C = (C â†’ P) for arbitrary proposition P. Traditional: C proves any P (logical explosion). PXL Analysis: Assume C âˆˆ ğ•†, then ğ•€â‚(C) must hold. C â‰¡ (C â†’ P) requires identity evaluation before implication. But ğ•€â‚(C) = ğ•€â‚(C â†’ P) creates reflexive dependency. Modal priority violated: (ğ•€â‚(C) â†’ ğ•€â‚(C â†’ P)) â†’ ğ•€â‚(C). This is circular grounding: ğ•€â‚(C) âŠ— (C â†’ ğ•€â‚(C)) = âŠ¥. Stratified Form forbids equating C with FImp (FTruth C) P at the same level. Formally: no_curry_fixed_point_term (PXL_WellFormedness) blocks any Packed equality between C : Form level and FImp (FTruth C) P : Form (S level). Therefore C is not admissible (not in ğ•†).
sections.notes: CRITICAL UNRESOLVED: No formal proof exists. Claimed lemma 'no_curry_fixed_point_term' not found in proof_index.json. Conceptual approach only.

sections.title: 23. Ship of Theseus (Identity Paradox)
sections.txt_claim: Statement: If a ship's parts are replaced gradually until none of the original parts remain, is it still the same ship? What if the original parts are reassembled? PXL Analysis: Identity ğ•€â‚(ship) can ground in multiple criteria: (i) material composition, (ii) functional role, (iii) spatiotemporal continuity, (iv) historical causal chain. Gradual replacement maintains (ii), (iii), (iv) while losing (i). Reassembly maintains (i) partially but breaks (iii) and (iv). Resolution: Identity grounding is multi-modal. No single criterion is privileged. Depending on which ğ•€â‚ mode is weighted, different answers are acceptable.
sections.notes: UNRESOLVED: No formal proof exists in proof_index.json. Conceptual multi-modal identity analysis, not formal resolution.

sections.title: 36. Omnipotence Paradox
sections.txt_claim: Statement: Can an omnipotent being create a stone so heavy it cannot lift it? PXL Analysis: Let B = omnipotent being, R = 'create stone unliftable by B'. Traditional: If B can do R, B is not omnipotent (cannot lift). If B cannot do R, B is not omnipotent (cannot create). PXL Resolution: R â‰¡ 'entity E such that â–¡(created_by(E, B) âˆ§ Â¬liftable_by(E, B))'. This requires: B creates E that logically constrains B's power, i.e., B âŸ¼ Â¬(B âŸ¼ lift(E)). This is: â–¡(B has power P) âˆ§ â–¡(B creates constraint Â¬P). Identity incoherence: B trying to ground Â¬B. Such R is not in ğ•† (domain of coherent being). Omnipotence = power to actualize all coherent possibilities, not incoherent pseudo-descriptions. Paradox dissolves: R is not a possible action but a logically malformed sentence outside ğ•†.
sections.notes: CRITICAL UNRESOLVED: No formal proof exists in proof_index.json. Conceptual analysis only. TXT claims dissolution but provides no formal proof or lemma reference.

sections.title: Summary of PXL Dissolution Methodology
sections.txt_claim: Common Patterns in Paradox Dissolution: 1. Self-Referential Paradoxes (Liar, Curry, Quine, Grelling-Nelson): Violation: Circular identity groundingâ€”attempting to establish ğ•€â‚ via operations that presuppose ğ•€â‚. Resolution: Entities fail ğ•€â‚-grounding requirement, exist outside ğ•†. 2. Set-Theoretic Paradoxes (Russell, Barber, Banach-Tarski): Violation: Attempting collection/entity formation without determinate identity criteria. Resolution: Purported sets/entities shown to be ğ•€â‚-incoherent, thus non-existent in ğ•†. 3-8. [Additional patterns listed].
sections.notes: Methodological summary of conceptual approach. No formal proofs provided. Explanatory framework only.

sections.title: Paradox Resolution Conclusion
sections.txt_claim: All paradoxes resolved categorically: either shown to be pseudo-entities outside ğ•† (domain of being), or revealed as counterintuitive but valid theorems, or dissolved through proper modal/causal/probabilistic analysis.
sections.notes: CRITICAL OVERCLAIM: TXT asserts 'All paradoxes resolved categorically' but zero formal proofs exist in proof_index.json for any of the 42 paradoxes listed. This is a sweeping claim without formal backing. Must be marked to_formalize.
